snippet: The leader of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, says it will stick to campaign tools like polls and political intuition in its future campaigns.
abstract: Manlio Fabio Beltrones, leader of Mexico's governing party, says it will cease practice of hiring neuroscientists as consultants for political advertising; decision follows outcry over practice that involved measuring voters' brain waves and reading their facial expressions.

byline.original: By ELISABETH MALKIN and KEVIN RANDALL
byline.contributor: Elisabeth Malkin reported from Mexico City, and Kevin Randall from Chicago.

lead_paragraph: The leader of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, says it will stick to campaign tools like polls and political intuition in its future campaigns.

headline.main: Mexico’s Governing Party Vows to Stop Using Neuromarketing to Study Voters
